summary: This document is an email chain from March 2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutors and FBI personnel regarding significant problems with the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The prosecutors express frustration over disorganized data, missing metadata linking emails to attachments, and a lack of clear accounting for over 60 seized devices.

persons.name: Christopher Rozier
persons.context: Appears as a recipient on the email chain, suggesting involvement in the evidence processing coordination.

events.title: 2007 Property Search
events.description: Search conducted on one of Jeffrey Epstein's properties, resulting in the seizure of hard drives.

events.title: Search Warrant Returns Provided
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office provided search warrant returns to the FBI, listing items seized from Epstein's properties.

events.title: Email Chain on Evidence Problems
events.description: SDNY prosecutors email FBI expressing major frustrations with the disorganized state of transferred digital evidence from Epstein searches, hindering their review.

locations: California (mentioned as travel destination for case team)
keyFacts: Prosecutors state the FBI is 'completely fucking us' on processing over 60 devices seized from Epstein's properties.
Over 1 million documents were received but are unusable because emails cannot be linked to their attachments (e.g., 'see the attached flight records' is unverifiable).
Nine IDE hard drives from Epstein's Manhattan apartment were copies of drives seized in a July 2007 search of another property.
Evidence was seized from two primary locations: Epstein's New York mansion (approx. 40+ devices and 60+ CDs) and his Virgin Islands property (over 25 devices including servers).
The data transfer lacked basic organization: load files didn't match native files, making large files 'completely invisible' for review and future production to defense counsel.
